question: What color hair does he have?
Making Hutch David Soul?
OK. That's wrong.
Plus where's Huggie Bear?
answer: He's not there. Huggie Bear isn't in every single episode.

question: I think you might of dreamed this one, Anthony.
answer: No. It's a real episode. The killer is leading him across the city by calling different pay phones.

question: Why?
answer: As part of his plan. I don't know why.

question: See, that's what I'm saying. It has the logic of a dream.
answer: The point is the killer always goes, May I speak to Starsky? He says his name.

question: What does Starsky say?
This is he?
answer: No. This is he. Did you see what I meant about the window?

question: Kind of. Except we've already got the keys.
answer: That's true. But what if they change the locks?

question: Would they do that?
answer: Who knows? That's why I filed it down. Now that window can never be locked. It's impossible.

question: See, your mind is very good with the more mechanical details. Whereas my strength would be --
answer: Sure. You don't see many women who like Tabasco. She's really kind of hot.

question: She's an attractive older woman.
I don't know, Bob. What about one of those?
answer: I'm not allowed to drive those.

question: Not even for emergencies?
I thought your parents were in Italy.
So who's going to know?
Yeah. I've stolen two cars before. One Jaguar. And one Trans-Am. With T-Tops. That Trans-Am was fun to drive.
Yes. I did.
It's true, Dignan.
answer: Well. What do you want to do? You want to steal one or just drive your car?

question: I'll just drive my car.
answer: Anthony, we'll get two hundred for the coin collection alone. That's less than what it's appraised at.

question: Anthony, we'll get two hundred for the coin collection alone. That's less than what it's appraised at.
answer: But Dignan, do you really know that much about rare coins?

question: I know about money, Anthony. I know the value of money. Plus the earrings are worth three times that. Your ball.
answer: I told you not to take the earrings.

question: You got another ball. I'm playing your game.
answer: The list, Dignan. I know you remember the list because you signed it. "Things Dignan was not supposed to touch."

question: Every valuable item in the house was on that list.
answer: That doesn't make any difference. I bought those earrings for my mother on her birthday. They have a very special value for her.

question: Yeah, but I can't be sorting through that shit in the middle of a burglary. There's just not time for it.
answer: Then you shouldn't of gone in there, Dignan. Maybe we should of robbed your house. Did you ever think of that? What? Where are you going?

question: I don't appreciate you ridiculing me.
You're making fun of my family. You know there's nothing to steal from my mom and Craig. You know exactly what you're saying.
answer: That's not what I meant, Dignan.

question: Did you see that?
I'm lookout.
I don't think so. Just reach on in.
No, just do it real quick. I'll meet you down there.
Yeah, I heard that.
Holy shit. What'd I tell you?
That's not bad.
answer: What do herbs have to do with it? I don't understand the --

question: Pot is an herb. It's just like any type of gardening.
answer: How much could you grow? Realistically.

question: As much as I want. When these plants bud I'll probably have about six thousand dollars worth of weed.
answer: Six thousand dollars? Come on, Bob.

question: You should take a look. I have an entire crop in my backyard.
answer: In your backyard? How do you protect them?

question: It's private property. Plus I have Hector.
But he's got a loud bark. That's the most important thing is a loud bark.
answer: If it's that easy why doesn't everybody grow them?

question: Good question. Don't you guys tell anybody about my plants.
Yeah, but don't tell anybody.
I don't know. Sure, I guess.
answer: You could make your own cinnamon toast.

question: Are you a fag?
Little Richard. I don't believe it. They'll let anybody in this place. Sit down. Dignan and Anthony, this is Little Richard. He's crazy. Totally nuts.
Little Richard. Trust me. You're insane. Jesus, this guy used to carry a percussion bomb around in his trunk. You do not want a guy like that loose on the streets.
answer: It seemed like a good idea at the time.

question: Anthony.
answer: OK. Break it up. Break it up.

question: I separated my shoulder.
Just pull straight up. Anthony pulls up hard on Dignan's arm. Dignan tries not to yell, then suddenly he's OK and relieved.
Yeah. No. I'm not fighting anymore.
answer: His shoulder went out, man. It's over.

question: The guy is fucking insane.
You said it like it was a big joke, Bob. Like he's wild.
answer: No, I was saying crazy like a lunatic.

question: I know that now. He's a fucking psycho.
answer: Well, don't blame me. I told you.

question: You blew it, Bob.
OK. Escape route. The most important thing you can have is an escape route. Just in case somebody's tailing us. Or even chasing us, as the case may be --
answer: You think we're going to be chased?

question: That's a good question. No. I don't. I'm just being hypocritical here. However, I will say --
answer: I'm going to take a look at this.

question: Hang on This is important, Bob. Anthony and I are responsible for the internal situation. The money and the people. You're responsible for the external situation. The streets and the getaway.
How many bullets can that hold?
I'm paying attention. I just want to look at it for a minute.
answer: What's your fucking problem? You're a shithead!

question: I just want to see how much bullets it takes.
answer: Anthony, give me the fucking gun!

question: God DAMMIT. You two just don't give a shit, do you?
You're out! I'm not working with either one of you!
answer: Dignan! Stop! Calm down. Take a deep breath.

question: You know, Bob, Anthony did kill someone. He electrocuted our janitor senior year.

It was an accidental. I don't want to go into the details. It was just one of those senior pranks that didn't really go right. I mean, obviously, since Swifty's dead. That's why Anthony never graduated.
Yeah. One of the nicest old guys you'd ever know.
You know, when somebody gets electrocuted, their skin starts smoking. At least Swifty's did.
Oh. I see. Come on in. We're closed, sir.
He left his sweater.
answer: Well, I left some money in there.

question: Where?
answer: In the cash relister. Step away from the door.

question: In the cash relister. Step away from the door.
Where's the other stocker?
We know there's another stocker.
Where is he? Where is Rob?
answer: I don't know. Maybe in literature. That's his section.

question: You got that?
answer: Sure. Literature. The classics. Is that the manager?

question: Unlock that door. Check the aisles.
answer: Rob? Why aren't you in literature?

question: Open it up. OK. Open the other. Let's go. Put it in one of those. A bigger one, you idiot. I'm sorry. But that bag's too small. OK, guys. Just...Sit tight. Go. Go. Drive slow.
Shhh. Slow down, Bob. Drive natural.
That's good. Keep it at forty.
We got it. We got it.
Don't count it.
answer: Was Dignan screaming like, Get me a bag!

question: Yeah. He said that.
answer: I swear to God. In a very quiet voice.

question: Like he meant it.
Like he would find Dignan. One day.
answer: Like I'm going to hunt you down and kill you.

question: See you, Bob.
answer: Hang on, Bob. That was really good driving. Seriously. I mean it. We'll see you later, Bob. Good driving. What's wrong with him?

question: What do you think?
answer: Anthony, he sat in the car and watched a 4-11 in progress. He got what he deserved.

question: He was the driver, Dignan. He did what he's supposed to do.
answer: I didn't realize you were so sensitive to Bob's feelings. Considering I did the plans, you're actually lucky you got --

question: Don't even say it, man.
Bob, will you please listen?
answer: I don't want to talk about it.

question: Look, I admit I was wrong for not telling you before the robbery that your share wouldn't be as equal as ours. But the fact remains me and Anthony were much more exposed to danger. I mean, Jesus Christ, Bob. You didn't have some vicious lunatic screaming, "I'm going to remember you!"
answer: That's true. That would give me nightmares.

question: Bob, I've got nightmares.
answer: You'll probably have them the rest of your life.

question: As soon as I opened the door I saw him. A black guy. Looking through my dad's tool box. I wanted to trap this guy. So I closed the garage door.
answer: And that's when he hit you?

question: He struck me. I fell down. He took my wallet. Then he opened the garage door and ran away.
How long do you have to go?
And what does that cover?
Hand to hand combat?
What the fuck is Dignan doing with that cop? He loves them.
answer: There's a million places to hide around here.

question: Oh, yeah. They'll never catch the guy.
Nobody does.
answer: Obviously. That's why we go on the road. The thing about cops is they have short attention spans. Can I get that credit card from you?

question: I don't like to use that credit card, Dignan.
Because my mom gets the bill.
answer: She's not going to notice, Anthony.

question: I don't want to use it.
answer: Well, then cut it in half.

question: I keep it for emergencies.
answer: Anthony, we're on the run. This is an emergency. It's only fair that...

question: Here's mine right here. See?
answer: See if mine are in there.

question: Dignan, those aren't running shoes.
Look at the treads on those.
They obviously weren't designed for racing.
answer: Well, those treads stink. You'd blow a knee out racing on those.

question: OK, Dad.
answer: Really. OK, Dad. But seriously, Anthony. These are fast shoes.

question: You've never had a pair of fast shoes in your life, Dignan. In fifth grade Dignan used to wear cowboy boots for P.E.
answer: That's real cool, Anthony. Yeah, I wore boots. My parents wouldn't buy me any $200 running shoes like yours. I wasn't spoiled.

question: Don't call me spoiled, Dignan.
You want to say it, Bob? I'll just say it.
OK. Go ahead.
answer: On your marks... Get set go. You owe me fifty bucks.

question: Bob wasn't even looking. What? Yeah. I think so.
answer: Look, man. She didn't know anything about shirts.

question: No, I'm not saying her. I'm just saying, I don't know.
answer: It's a great shirt. Don't worry about it.

question: Armored trucks are very difficult to steal, Anthony.
answer: I know. But once you get inside you're home free.

question: Right.. Get back to me on that one. Once your plan is worth a shit.
answer: It's not a plan. It's just --

question: Actually. If you knew the exact route, you could plant explosives under a manhole cover and blow it up as it went over.
answer: Yeah, but you wouldn't have the truck if you blew it up.

question: I'm sure he did. We'll have to get new plates.
answer: It's registered in my mother's name.

question: What the fuck possessed you?
answer: You're the one who kept saying ram him.

question: I meant tap him. As a warning.
answer: Dignan, I can't get my hair cut. That's just not possible, all right?

question: Then you're going to have to dye it, Anthony. We've got to hide our identities. Especially after Bob crashed the car.
answer: No, Dignan. I'm sorry. I can't do that.

question: See you, Bob. No, it's OK. Come on in. It's hot out, isn't it? Yeah. This is a nice little town. So, what, do you do all these rooms yourself? Or what? I'm Anthony. What's your name? Inez? Let me give you a hand with that. How do you say nineteen?
Right. Yeah. Yo soy dies y nueve. How old are you? Are you ever scared of finding a dead body in one of these rooms?

It could happen. This is the exact kind of place where it happens. But I don't want to scare you. People think because they're in a hotel they can act like a slob. It's bad manners. Were you born in Mexico?
Oh, really? That's interesting. Do you prefer Cuba or the United States?
These towels are still warm. I guess from the dryer. I've never met anybody from Cuba before.
You can go first, Bob.
What are you talking about?
But it's not his. How can they arrest Future Man?
answer: They said he's a drug dealer.

question: Those assholes. We got rapes. Murders. Violent crimes every second. And this is what they come up with. They're just fucking him because he's from a prominent family. I don't think they can make it stick, Bob. I mean, what do they actually have on Future Man?
answer: Well, the marijuana crop is a good start.

question: That could be anybody's.
answer: They also found my two beam scale in the garage.

question: Since when is it a crime to have a scale in your house? Everybody has a scale.
answer: The cops say it's a special kind of scale drug dealers use in selling marijuana.

question: So tell them the truth. What do you use it for?
answer: I was just going to use it to see how much I had.

question: How long has he been in there?
Then how come they haven't set the bail yet? That's unconstitutional.
answer: We'll have to see when we get back.

question: What do you mean get back?
answer: Well, obviously, we got to go back.

question: Bob, that makes no sense.
answer: Dignan, he's my brother. I can't just leave him there.

question: This could be a trap.
Don't "Come on, Dignan" me.
Not in that car you're not.
Good luck, since I got the keys.
I can't do that, Bob.
answer: Dignan. You're going to give me those keys or you're going to get hurt.

question: Don't threaten me, Bob.
answer: Goddammit, Dignan! It's my car! If you don't give me my keys, I swear to God --

question: Look, Bob. I understand your loyalty. You're a good person. But right now you're not using your best judgement. Future Man would not want you to go to jail I promise you. Just get in the car and we'll talk about it. Future Man would never go to jail for you, I'll tell you that.
answer: His name's not Future Man, Dignan.

question: I know it's not.
answer: You don't even know his name.

question: Yes, I do.
Just get in the car, Bob.

OK, Bob. I don't know his name. You know why? Because I don't care. He's Future Man. But I care about you. And to me it doesn't make sense to go back to the scene of a crime. Will you get in the car, Bob? This is stupid.
answer: It's not your decision and he's not your brother, Dignan.

question: That's right. I only have one vote. We'll go talk with Anthony and figure it out. You're going to ride in the back? Come on, Bob. Get in front. You've got a beautiful walk, Bob.
Hi. How's it going.
answer: I thought you guys went to get your hair cut.

question: No. We didn't.
answer: We're making banana daqueris. This is Inez. Carmen. Anita.

question: Hi.
Jerry. And this is my associate Cornelius. May I have a word with you, please?
What the fuck is going on here?
Anthony, we're on the run from the law here. Did you tell these people your real name?
answer: No. I didn't. Dignan, they don't speak English.

question: They don't?
answer: No. Not really. Inez speaks a little.

question: Which one was that?
answer: On the left. She's from Cuba.

question: And if Future Man doesn't get let out of jail in 48 hours, then we go back. All right?
answer: Now that makes sense. We'll hang out for a couple of days. Get a little R&R. Make sure Future Man's OK and then get back on the road.

question: As long as he gets out OK.
God. That does sound corny. Oh, your skin feels so soft and silky. But it really kind of does.
answer: No lifeguard on duty. Swim at your own risk. You know, I did save Anthony from drowning once, Inez. Tell her, Anthony. See, one day we were playing hot box over at my next door neighbor Mr. Langston's house and Anthony fell in the pool and got knocked unconscious. I had to dive in and save him.

question: This was in fourth grade.
answer: Mr. Langston performed cardiopulmonary recitation. CPR. I've never said this before, but frankly I thought Anthony was dead. The veins in his face were all sticking out. His skin was blue. He truly did look dead.

question: After that my parents never let me go to Dignan's again.
answer: They blamed my family for everything. They always said Mr. Langston saved Anthony's life.

question: But if it wasn't for Dignan I probably would of died.
Son of a bitch. He's gone. He stole the car.
Right here. That coward. Son of a bitch.
answer: Maybe he just went to the store.

question: He took his stuff. He's gone. I should of seen this. I should of expected it. Bob doesn't have any character.
answer: He went back for his brother.

question: We said 48 hours.
answer: That's a long time to be in jail.

question: We'll get him. Don't worry about that. We'll go back. We'll find him. And we'll blow up his car. Or do something. I promise you. I mean, let's face it. Bob was dead weight. We're a lot better off without him. But who could expect it? Just like that. Steals the fucking car. What kind of person pulls that --
answer: Bob didn't steal the car. He told me he was going. He had to go help his brother.

question: When'd he tell you?
Where was I?
He told you and you let him do it.
answer: He told me because he wanted to know if I wanted to go.

question: If you wanted to go? What were you going to do? Just leave me here by myself?
answer: Well, I didn't do it, did I?

question: So when you were saying Bob's at the store and acting real suprised, that was just an act. You were just --
answer: Bob went to help his brother. I understand that and I can't help it if you don't.

question: I understand that if I had a few more friends like you and Bob I'd be dead.
If you'd gone with Bob you'd probably be in Weatherford by now. Of course I'd be here frantically worrying thinking you must of got kidnapped.
answer: I didn't realize you had such an incredible ability to feel sorry for yourself, Dignan.

question: Well, the world is a little bit colder today.
answer: You want to look at the map? See. Here's where we are.

question: I didn't know he had it in him. I guess you could say the child has become the father of the man.
answer: We're going over to this bar if you feel like going.

question: No. I'm going to swim. I'll see you later.
answer: Why don't you come with us.

question: Hello, my friend. You in the Army, yes?
answer: No. I just have short hair.

question: Is that your chiquita?
She Chicano, yes? You like Chicanos?
Play pool? For one cerveza. You a good pool player.
Where's your friend? He go with the chiquita?
She is a good looking woman.
Si. Tecate. You like to fight?
Fight. You know.
You Hoto?
No. Me no Hoto. Tecate?
I can't believe he just jumped you.
answer: Can you hand me those french fries.

question: I wish I'd been there.
Man. I'm sorry. We just went for a walk --
answer: I don't really feel like talking about it. The only thing I feel like is getting the fuck out of this place.

question: We need a car.
answer: I have an idea for that.

question: What?
answer: Inez has a master key to all these rooms, doesn't she? Doesn't she?

question: I don't think we can do that.
answer: I know we can. It's real simple. We go into a room, grab some car keys and --

question: What I'm saying is she wouldn't go for that.
I don't know, Dignan. I just --
answer: Look. I'm ready to get the fuck out of here. It's real torture for me to be here. Getting the shit kicked out of me by Mexicans.

question: Shh.
answer: No one to back me up. Now I have a good idea. So unless you come up with something better --

question: Dignan. I can't do that. All right? I just can't.
answer: Then you better think of something.

question: I feel great, Inez.
answer: I'll see you later. I don't think we need any keys, Dignan. I think I can hotwire a car for us.

question: You don't know how to hotwire.
answer: Yes, I do. Bob taught me.

question: Bob taught you how to get electrocuted.
answer: No, I'm serious. He made me a diagram.

question: What'd you say to Inez? "I'll come back for you. I love you, Inez." "I'm going to take you away from all this windexing and making beds."
answer: Man, I don't know anything about cars.

question: You really know how to pick them.
answer: I think we better go home.

question: Don't panic, Anthony.
You can't just run home every time things get tough. First of all, we've got enough dough to --
answer: Our money situation is not good.

question: You're so spoiled. What is "not good" to you? Only a few hundred --
That's not correct. Give it to me. Sixteen dollars.
Where's the rest?
answer: I had to give some to Inez.

question: How much?
What! You gave $383 to the goddamn housekeeper! What the fuck is your problem?
A $500 tip! For the housekeeper!
answer: Her name's Inez. Stop calling her the housekeeper.

question: That's what she is!
You're in love with the fucking housekeeper!
What are you going to do, get married? Have a bunch of little idiot janitor brats! And go around scrubbing the --
answer: Stop! Now listen to me. Bob, where you going?

question: Stop! Now listen to me. Bob, where you going?
answer: I'm not playing any more golf.

question: Why not?
answer: Cause I'm not getting any better. It's a waste of time.

question: You've only been playing for two weeks, Bob. It takes a long time to learn this game.
Yes. You just got to stick with it.
answer: You don't have to talk about it if you don't want to.

question: No, I don't mind.
answer: I know it must of been a bad experience. But it doesn't sound like it was your fault.

question: Well, I didn't mean to electrocute him. But the whole operation was my idea. It took six months of research. I did all the wiring myself. Switched AC to DC. Doubled the voltage. Shorted out the generator. The whole school was shut down.
answer: That's pretty complicated for a senior prank.

question: I don't like that word prank, Bob. I was trying to do something more than a prank. I wanted to create an event. Something everyone would remember. And at first it worked perfectly. The whole school was standing around outside. Kids running all over the place. Everybody laughing. Even the school custodian Swifty thought it was great. He kept laughing and shaking his head the whole time he tried to disconnect the generator. And then suddenly total silence except for Swifty hanging off the generator with his leg stuck to it being electrocuted. Actually he died of a heart attack brought on by the shock. He was an older guy. I felt terrible. I'd known Swifty since first grade. He was Dignan's medicine man for Indian Guides. They called each other Rattlesnake and Killer Whale. Whenever Dignan came to visit me he would act like he and Swifty weren't that good of friends, but that was just to make me feel better. The whole rest of the school had turned against me. At first they were going to charge me with manslaughter. That's partly why I was in custody so long. Sixty days.
Yeah. One minute you're studying Great Expectations and the next minute you're drawing the Holy Mary for some kid who tried to stab his girlfriend.
answer: Why were you drawing the Holy Mary?

question: I thought he didn't have to pay anything because of the technicality.
answer: Yeah, but he still has the aggravation. Three days sitting in a cell.

question: Were you adopted, Bob?
Well, because you guys don't look alike.
Was Future Man adopted?
There's a lot of valuable shit in there, Applejack. The silver and the china. The crystal. And the grandfather clock. Goddammit, I bet that clock's worth ten grand.
answer: Why the fuck do we need to blow up the car? It doesn't make any goddamn sense.

question: Just settling an old score. You might say revenge.
answer: That sounds like a lot of bullshit that'll land us in jail.

question: We might have to take that chance. Cause I feel pretty strongly about this.
Get down.
Wait a second. That's Anthony.
Yeah.
Looks like he's staying with Buckethead. That's what I figured. He's probably got his own room. Let's see where he's going. Don't get too close. Stop. He saw us. Wait. Did he see us?
answer: We're going too slow. It looks like we're following him.

question: Speed up. Anthony! Wait up. Where you going?
answer: Just walking Hector. When'd you get back?

question: Ah. Couple days ago. You want to shake hands.
That's Applejack. You want to meet him?
This is Applejack.
Applejack would of got him anyway. This was just the quicker war.
answer: You really hit a guy with a bottle?

question: Pretty much. He kind of fell into me. But wait a second. I want you to look at this.
It's big, Anthony. Real big. It's called Hinckley Cold Storage.
Let me feel that. Ow. Shit.
Mr. Henry?
It's locked.
This is no good. This is no good, bringing him here. What are you thinking? What the shit, man? Are you crazy? I'm pulling your leg. Abe Henry. This is my business manager, Rowboat.
That's a sharp jacket.
answer: Thanks. It's hard to get much spin with this kind of paddle.

question: It's called a racquet, Anthony, and you're holding it wrong. That's ghetto play. Hold it like this. You know, your form is for shit, but you've got a hell of a talent.
Yeah. Convert it into lofts. OK. Pop quiz. What's the single most important aspect of your job?
Crowd control. Crowd control. Wake up, guys.
Hey, Dignan. How's it going?
Come on in. What you been up to?
It's too bad about what happened on the road.
It was stupid.
I don't expect an apology and I don't even want one. I just want us to --
answer: I can't fucking believe this guy. An apology, Bob?

question: Cause you would of let my brother rot in jail.
I never agreed to that.
Bullshit.
answer: All right! Backyard! Right now! Let's go, Bob!

question: How you doing, Bob?
You keeping out of trouble?
This boy's a troublemaker. He used to tear this place apart. Your brother was up here the other day. He said you ran away from home.
He said you ran away from home.
answer: No. I didn't run away. I went out of town.

question: Fancy seeing you here, Bob.
So what's shaking?
Jackson says you told him I ran away from home.
John, I'm twenty-six years old I didn't run away from home.
answer: I know, Bob. You were on a secret mission.

question: I'd appreciate it if you didn't go around telling people lies about me.
answer: Right. I'm sorry. You've got a reputation to think about.

question: Right. I'm sorry. You've got a reputation to think about.
What?
answer: The world needs dreamers. To relieve the pain of consciousness.

question: Well, we'll see you later, Bob.
Nice to meet you.
answer: I hope this doesn't offend you, Bob. Your brother is a cocksucker.

question: OK. Man in blue jeans just left by southwest door. He is entering a white van. What time is it?
OK. Mark that down.
God. Isn't this great? Working on the job. Got a wheel man. Got a safecracker. Good friends with Mr. Henry.
Look at that woman. She's what? Fifty? Fifty-five? But she hasn't let herself go. I appreciate an older woman who has a commitment to her body.
Tell me something. What the hell kind of name is Dignan?
answer: I'm not really sure. I think it's Irish. Or maybe --

question: I guess what I'm trying to say is what the hell kind of person is this Dignan?
answer: What do you mean what kind of person? He's a good person.

question: Sure, sure. He's a great person, and I'd call bullshit on anybody who said differently. But I wonder if the kid has the goods up here.
answer: I don't think you're giving him enough credit. I know sometimes he doesn't think an idea through. He gets too excited. But --

question: As far as I can tell he hasn't thought his life through. He'd be fine cutting my grass or parking my car. But business? You I can work with. You I could groom. Dignan's not going to make it.
answer: You're wrong about Dignan. And you're wrong if you think, I'd turn my back on a friend.

question: Hold it. Anthony. I want.to say one thing to you. Congratulations. You passed the test.
The Abe Henry double-cross test. You just made a perfect score.
Take a deep breath. How does that feel?
answer: It feels good. Did Dignan take the test?

question: Yes, he did.
Well, he agreed 100% that Bob should be dropped. And he also agreed you were a liability. But he felt his talent would make up for your weaknesses.
Woah. There he is. Applejack! What it is.
answer: Is my car OK out there?

question: I love it. He always wants to know if the car's OK. Get a hot dog.
Super K. Kumar. Come here.
answer: I don't know why the fuck we're having a party. The damn job's not over yet.

question: I don't know why the fuck we're having a party. The damn job's not over yet.
answer: Well, this isn't really a party per se.

question: You don't celebrate til it's over.
What the fuck are you doing?
I'll tell you, Anthony. Times like this I get philosophical. What does it mean? What's it all about? Are you afraid to die?
No, that door over there.
Are you afraid?
answer: Yeah. I mean, I don't think about it all the time. But once in awhile I kind of go, Woah. Man.

question: Exactly. Woah.
The fear of death, The pain of consciousness. Did you mix this martini?
Bob. Bob. That's a palindrome. I love palindromes.
answer: Are you afraid to die, Mr. Henry?

question: If someone could copy my life story. If I had someone, man, to just write what I talk. I have so many stories. Bestseller, man.
answer: I've been all over the Goddamn country. I've seen things.

question: I used to go to Vegas and do headstands.
Good.
We're just going over a few things.
answer: I'll tell you something, Dignan. It is possible to overplan. You don't want to turn the crew into robots. Right? You got to have fun with it. There's no point if you're not having any fun. Would you like me to be there tomorrow?

question: Yes.
Well, I think --
answer: No, if I go out on this job, then it's just another score by Mr. Henry. And I don't see it like that. This is your job. Your creation. I want you to try this.

question: No, if I go out on this job, then it's just another score by Mr. Henry. And I don't see it like that. This is your job. Your creation. I want you to try this.

I want to ask a favor, boys. One day, when I'm long gone and all but forgotten, make one last toast to Abe Henry. And remember me as a friend. Well, that's just it, Anthony. A lot of criminals have problems. Some of them are alcoholics. Some have drug problems. Others dome from broken homes. I see a real need for healing. But you're thieves. It's what you are.
It's an esoteric journey. We're renegades from despair.
answer: Can I ask you something, Mr. Henry?

question: Absolutely.
answer: Why'd you want to help us?

question: Next week we'll be drinking pia coladas.
answer: Hopefully this trip'll go a little smoother than the last one. Or I might end up with a broken nose.

question: Did that hurt? This'll be a good trip.
answer: I'll try not to hold you back tomorrow.

question: I don't think you will.
answer: I don't want to be too much of a liability.

question: Look, you're going to do fine. It's OK to be scared.
answer: I don't think I ever said this to you. But it meant a lot to me the way you were after that Swifty stuff happened. He was a nice guy.

question: He was all right.
As a person?
Yes. I do.
answer: So do I. You OK, Bob?

question: Bird Dog to Scarecrow. Bird Dog to Scarecrow.
You're all clear.
We all set?
answer: Hang on a second. OK. Let's do it. Let's get lucky, Bird Dog.

question: Hang on a second. OK. Let's do it. Let's get lucky, Bird Dog.

answer: It looks pretty good. There's nobody back here.

question: Stand by. Bird Dog?
Take your second position.
OK. Six minutes.

answer: Why did he go that way?

Any activity?
answer: Not at all. The place is totally deserted.

question: Good. It's supposed to be.
answer: I've got a great view up here. I can see all the --

question: Stand by, Bird Dog. Jacknife. Come in, Jacknife. Hello? Bob? Are you there? Bob? What the fuck is going on? Anthony? Who's in the elevator?
Check the fucking elevator. It's moving.
Is he breathing?
Jesus Christ. What the fuck is that?
answer: I didn't think there was an alarm.

question: Take him to the car, Bob. Who tripped the alarm?
answer: It's the fire alarm. Somebody pulled the fire alarm.

question: I'll see you there.
I'll see you there.

Tell Mr. Henry I said that. So is Mr. Henry going to come by and see me or anything?
answer: I don't think so. I mean. Actually, he robbed Bob's house.

question: He did?
You got to be kidding me.
What'd he get?
His health isn't very good, you know. They take that into account.

Nothing.
It belongs to Bob's uncle.
Temporarily.
Behind Bob's house.
We're not sure yet. It's going to need some repairs. So how is it in there?
answer: What can I say? It's jail. You don't sleep when you want to. You don't eat when you want to.

question: What can I say? It's jail. You don't sleep when you want to. You don't eat when you want to.
answer: Do you have your own room?

question: We don't have rooms, Bob. We have cells.
answer: Do you have your own cell?
